2.93.text:
we may be listening
to a future president.

6.57.text:
I want to thank you,
Mr. Prime Minister.

9.47.text:
It was a pleasure having an
opportunity to spend some time

12.73.text:
with you as well, and Speaker
of the Chamber of Deputies,

16.13.text:
and the President of the Senate,
and the Justice Minister,

21.00.text:
and to all the
distinguished guests here,

24.57.text:
it's a great honor to be
in this magnificent venue

28.00.text:
and at such an important time
in U.S.-Romanian relations.

34.67.text:
Laura, thank you for
the introduction,

36.47.text:
but more importantly, thank you
for your continuing involvement.

40.73.text:
As I -- the first time our paths
crossed was five years ago,

45.53.text:
as you said, and
look at you now,

48.73.text:
pursuing an advanced
degree, an advocate

53.03.text:
And you are a reflection of
the progress your country

57.07.text: has made and continues to make.

62.13.text:
leaders of the parliament,
thank you all for coming.

66.37.text:
In America, for all those of
you who are public officials,

71.63.text:
" having to listen to another
public official make a speech.

75.33.text:
But I'm flattered
that you are here.

78.13.text:
And the fact that
you're here, I think,

79.73.text:
is a reflection of the common
recognition that while there may

83.53.text:
be political differences, one
thing that unites all Romanian

88.80.text:
leaders is a strong stand
in favor of democracy under

93.73.text:
the rule of law without question
and without any caveats.

98.97.text:
I want to thank you all, but I
particularly want to thank the

102.00.text:
civil society members here today
for demanding greater freedoms,

106.57.text:
fairness and social justice, and
maybe most importantly dignity

112.30.text: for all the people of Romania.

114.10.text:
There is a great expectation I
will say to those of you who are

120.33.text:
the younger members of the
audience -- there's a great

124.40.text:
expectation not only of the
people of Romania but the people

127.90.text:
in Europe and the United States
that nations who join the

133.87.text:
alliance, both in NATO as
well as the EU have a shared

142.10.text:
It's the value system
that is the foundation

146.93.text:
It's what built the
alliance in the first place.

150.87.text:
And the most fundamental of
these values is not a free

156.20.text:
market; it's an open, free,
and transparent society,

162.67.text:
where corruption is
viewed as the enemy,

165.83.text:
where government is
honest and accountable,

169.50.text:
and people are given a fair
opportunity at success and all

175.37.text:
-- regardless of their station
-- are treated with dignity.

179.77.text:
As I said when I visited five
years ago as I became Vice

183.73.text:
President, the story of freedom
-- your society -- is one

190.37.text:
of the great achievements in
modern European history.

194.90.text:
I admire -- and I mean this
sincerely -- I admire both the

198.10.text:
moral and physical courage so
many Romanians demonstrated

204.03.text:
who put everything on the line,
everything including their

208.17.text:
lives, to build this new,
free, democratic society.

213.93.text:
And I'm proud that America
played a small part

218.07.text:
in helping you
make that journey.

219.73.text:
And as I told Romanian
troops last night,

225.60.text:
when I met them as I
got off of the aircraft,

229.23.text:
American troops are honored to
stand shoulder to shoulder with

235.23.text:
Tricolor warriors as NATO
allies in Afghanistan

240.83.text:
and other places
we've stood together.

244.23.text:
And one other important point to
make I've made to the President

247.27.text:
and the Prime Minister today in
my separate meetings: America's

251.47.text:
commitment to the collective
defense under Article 5

256.70.text:
of the NATO Treaty is
absolutely ironclad.

261.03.text:
It's a sacred commitment in
the eyes of the President

265.87.text:
As President Obama said, "NATO
nations never stand alone."

280.10.text:
And one of the most remarkable
changes in this relationship

283.93.text:
from years past is we no longer
discuss what America can do for

290.13.text:
Romania, we discuss what we can
do together for one another.

296.83.text:
Romania has made a remarkable
journey from tyranny to freedom,

302.67.text:
from captive nation to NATO
ally -- and it happened,

307.37.text:
it's happened in the space
of a single generation.

312.43.text:
For you younger members
of the audience,

318.37.text:
And as one of America's
Founding Fathers said,

321.67.text:
his name was Thomas
Jefferson, he observed that,

331.60.text:
Well, I'm here to tell you
it's your job to complete --

336.97.text:
And when you do, your children's
generation will be eternally

342.47.text:
grateful because it will
solidify for the remainder of

346.37.text:
this century the democracy
your parents fought

352.20.text:
For any young democracy, the
most difficult but important

356.90.text:
step is burying the legacy
of tyranny and establishing

365.40.text:
an economy and a government
and institutions that abide

373.33.text:
Every country faces challenges
to the rule of law,

379.27.text:
And the choices each of our
countries make matter immensely

386.13.text:
-- not only for our own
country, but for our neighbors.

389.97.text:
In the 21st century, the
countries that thrive will be

395.87.text:
the ones where citizens know
their voices will be heard

403.93.text:
Their efforts will be rewarded
because there is a fairness

408.77.text:
in the court system; where
businesses can compete

413.80.text:
without having to worry
about paying bribes;

417.07.text:
where judges hand down verdicts
free from political influence.

422.57.text:
The European Commission recently
found that corruption costs

429.10.text:
the European Union as a
whole $160 billion,

433.40.text:
or 120 billion euros
every single year.

439.47.text:
That's 1 percent of the
total GDP of the entire

446.47.text:
Corruption is a cancer, a cancer
that eats away at a citizen's

452.87.text:
faith in democracy, diminishes
the instinct for innovation

463.90.text:
budgets, crowding out important
national investments.

469.77.text:
It wastes the talent
of entire generations.

474.67.text:
It scares away
investments and jobs.

479.90.text:
And most importantly it denies
the people their dignity.

485.60.text:
It saps the collective strength
and resolve of a nation.

490.30.text:
Corruption is just
another form of tyranny.

496.47.text:
And corruption can represent a
clear and present danger not

501.80.text:
only to a nation's economy, but
to its very national security.

508.93.text:
There are nations, and
we've seen it recently,

513.63.text:
that exploit corruption to
exercise malign influence and

520.97.text:
undermine the very
sovereignty and independence

527.83.text:
In this way, corruption has
become an instrument of foreign

537.27.text:
When politicians can be bought,
when courts can be manipulated,

542.63.text:
when the media becomes
a tool of propaganda,

547.40.text:
there you will find a
society that is susceptible

555.70.text:
There you'll find a society
that loses control of its

559.67.text:
own destiny -- not only its
political security,

565.23.text:
but its physical security
and military readiness

571.43.text:
We've recently seen
that in Ukraine.

574.47.text:
We saw how over a decade
and a half of corruption,

578.60.text:
literally has hollowed out
their military institutions

583.60.text:
and weakened that country's very
capacity to defend itself.

589.57.text:
So fighting corruption is more
than just good government.

599.97.text:
It's a guarantor of your
national sovereignty.

605.37.text:
Many of you, inside
government and out,

608.07.text:
have been working to root
out corruption for years.

613.20.text:
And I applaud you
all for your efforts.

616.97.text:
With your help, Romania has
made significant achievements

623.57.text:
Your National Anti-Corruption
Agency has firmly established

628.10.text:
its independence and sent
1,000 cases to court

636.60.text:
Your National Integrity
Agency sent forward 6,

640.53.text:
000 cases of incompatibility
-- people holding office that

645.30.text:
should be mutually exclusive
-- and 50 cases of elected

656.10.text:
Of course there's work to do
to see these cases through,

664.03.text:
It's no wonder that your
anti-corruption institutions

667.63.text:
are the most highly rated
institutions in Romania in the

675.40.text:
You have heroes like the Supreme

679.63.text:
to protect the independence of

688.17.text:
Romanian citizens are getting
directly involved as well,

693.23.text: many of you in this audience.

695.80.text:
From high school students
learning in your classrooms

699.57.text:
not to pay bribes to
avoid traffic tickets,

702.03.text:
to young professionals holding
"check-a-thons" to demand

706.40.text:
honesty from politicians
and hold them accountable.

708.93.text:
I understand some of you
may be here fact-checking

719.53.text:
For corruption is a complex and
difficult problem to solve

725.37.text:
in all countries, but
it can be solved.

730.87.text:
I strongly urge you to keep
taking steps forward and keep

736.93.text:
resisting the
instinct to step back.

740.27.text:
Keep demanding that your
judicial institutions remain

743.77.text:
free from political influence;
keep insisting that no one --

750.87.text:
no one -- no one
is above the law.

755.97.text:
Now, some of you may argue
this focus on transparency

760.83.text:
is a foreign invention that
doesn't apply to Romania.

768.87.text:
Romanians have been fighting
corruption for a long time.

773.60.text:
I was recently told a
story, an old story of Cuza,

779.93.text:
the founder of modern Romania,
who as legend has it disguised

785.77.text:
himself as a peasant
and went to the market.

790.27.text:
He pretended to buy milk from
a merchant who was cheating

794.20.text:
customers by using two
different measuring cups.

799.77.text:
The large one he
showed to the customer,

803.20.text:
and the small one he used
to actually measure out

809.87.text:
The ruler revealed his identity,
confronted the crooked merchant,

815.60.text:
and forced him to parade through
the marketplace with his two

819.77.text:
measuring cups held high where
everybody could see them --

824.40.text: the real one and the fake one.

828.10.text:
And no one bought from
that merchant again.

831.67.text:
It's a parable, but it says
a lot about how modern day

837.47.text:
economic investors think
about the global marketplace.

844.00.text:
They want to do business
where they're treated fairly,

847.57.text:
and where there is
transparency, where they know

851.83.text: the real cup from the phony cup.

856.57.text:
Of course no leader -- in
Cuza's time or in our own --

861.47.text:
can hope to protect these
principles alone.

865.47.text:
I have worked on this
issue around the world.

868.40.text:
And I've seen how it's done well
and where it's done poorly.

873.67.text:
And I've learned that it takes
fearless judges, brave police,

879.53.text:
and prosecutors working 14
hours a day to investigate

885.43.text:
complex crimes -- ignoring
pressure and intimidation

891.03.text: to ensure that justice is done.

893.93.text:
It takes leaders in the business
community who recognize that

898.50.text:
fighting corruption is good for
everyone because it improves

904.50.text:
the business climate and
generates economic growth.

908.07.text:
It takes politicians who
understand that government

911.83.text:
exists not for our purposes
but to serve the people.

918.43.text:
And it takes a free and
independent press -- under

923.27.text:
no one's thumb -- with
the protections necessary

928.90.text:
to hold all of us who are
leaders accountable.

933.90.text:
And above all, it takes
an active, passionate,

944.53.text: like all of you in this room.

947.03.text:
Because as surely as a man
cannot live without blood

951.73.text:
pumping through his veins,
democracy cannot survive without

957.17.text:
the active participation
of its citizens.

961.03.text:
That's what we mean when
we say civil society

969.77.text: In a literal sense it is.

973.23.text:
We count on civil society to
shine a light on injustice;

979.33.text:
to give voice to minorities
and marginalized groups;

986.97.text:
And here in "Unity Hall," we
look to all of you to champion

998.77.text:
the dignity, the protections,
the fundamental human rights

1003.27.text:
of all people -- of women,
of Roma, of Jews, of LGBT.

1010.73.text:
And they deserve to be treated
equally and with respect.

1015.13.text:
There's always going to
be cynics and doubters.

1018.57.text:
But I urge you to never forget
that civil society has changed

1026.33.text: And it can do it again.

1030.10.text:
And this is an urgent
time for all of Central

1035.53.text:
and Eastern Europe for civil
societies to be awakened.

1040.80.text:
As the saying goes, democracy
is not a destination.

1050.53.text:
So long as you travel this
road, you will never be alone.

1057.17.text:
You will have the United States
and many other countries as your

1060.40.text:
allies, your friend, your
fellow free nations standing

1065.03.text:
by your side because we
face a different kind

1069.93.text:
of threat today than we
did even a year ago.

1076.67.text:
We face a different kind of
threat that preys upon nations

1084.10.text:
who are not just weak, but whose
governments are not solid,

1095.20.text:
Your government is
making great progress.

1098.23.text:
The people of Romania are
making great progress.

1101.60.text:
And I'll conclude by saying
what I said to both your Prime

1105.53.text:
Minister and your President, I
cannot imagine a Europe whole,

1112.80.text:
free and secure
without a strong,

1122.17.text:
So it's not only in your
interest and the interest of

1127.67.text:
your countrymen to deal in
a way that delivers for your

1133.77.text:
constituents and for your
people, the stronger you are,

1138.80.text:
the more independent you,
the more capable you are,

1141.53.text: the better off we all are.

1145.50.text:
As I said, it's not what
America can do for Romania,

1150.23.text:
it's what we can do
together for one another.

1156.27.text:
May God bless America, and may
God protect our Romanian and

1161.03.text:
American troops who are still
in harm's way in Afghanistan.

1166.27.text:
Thank you all for the honor
of being able to address you.
